items.title: A role for condensin-mediator interaction in mitotic chromosome organization
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69270-x Accurate chromosome segregation relies on three-dimensional genome organization, yet its molecular basis remains unclear. Here, the authors identify an interaction between the condensin and the mediator complexes. Its disruption disturbs mitotic gene expression, chromatin domain formation, and chromosome segregation.

items.title: Decoding phantom limb movements from intraneural recordings
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69297-0 Decoding motor intents from peripheral nerves remains challenging. The authors record intraneural sciatic activity in transfemoral amputees and use a spiking neural network to decode phantom leg movements. These findings support bidirectional, neurally-controlled prosthetic systems.

items.title: Uncovering Cas9 PAM diversity through metagenomic mining and machine learning
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69098-5 CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing is constrained by the need for a protospacer adjacent motif (PAM) at the target site. Here, the authors combine metagenomic mining with machine learning to map and predict PAM specificities across thousands of Cas9 enzymes, expanding the genomic target space.

items.title: Electrostatic properties of disordered regions control transcription factor search and pioneer activity
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69284-5 This work describes how positive charge in the peptide chain flanking the DNA-binding domain of transcription factors speeds up their search on free and chromatinized DNA, helping to explain why some transcription factors act as stronger pioneers.

items.title: A combinatorial synthetic strategy for developing genome-editing protein-delivery agents targeting mouse retina
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69077-w Precise and efficient CRISPR genome editing requires specialized delivery systems. Here, the authors develop Coomassie lipidoids that deliver purified adenine base editors into retinal tissues, making it possible to achieve robust genome editing with a defined, non-viral nanomedicine.

items.title: Interleukin-10 expressing B lineage cells in visceral adipose tissue protect against aging-related insulin resistance and extend lifespan
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69371-7 Aging is characterised by visceral adipose tissue (VAT) inflammation but the molecular mechanisms driving or inhibiting the VAT-driven processes are not fully known. Here the authors identify BAFF as a soluble mediator in VAT to promote the expansion of regulatory B cells that produce IL-10 to inhibit aging-related inflammation.

items.title: Neuromorphic photonic computing with an electro-optic analog memory
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-69084-x Neuromorphic photonic systems can incur significant energy for moving and converting data between digital and analog domains. This work shows that integrating analog memory into these processors can save 26 × power over conventional digital-to-analog architectures while keeping > 90% inference accuracy.

items.title: Radical footprinting in mammalian whole blood
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 February 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68982-4 Radical protein footprinting reveals protein structure and interactions, but has not – to the best of the authors knowledge - been applied in whole blood. Here, authors demonstrate in-blood footprinting in mice, uncovering diabetes-associated protein conformational changes that were validated by orthogonal assays.

items.summary: Demonstrating the exchange statistics of Majorana zero modes is a key step towards topological quantum computing. Recent progress in artificial Kitaev chains motivates this work, which develops a protocol for Majorana exchange. The authors define here a protocol to facilitate exchange, identify platform-specific challenges, study relevant noise sources, and analyze remedies and experimental constraints. With its results, the study provides practical guidance towards realizing braiding in artificial Kitaev chains.

items.title: Field theory of Borromean supercounterfluids
authors: Anatoly Kuklov, Leo Radzihovsky, and Boris Svistunov
items.summary: A Borromean counter-flow superfluid (BCSF) is a highly entangled state of N > 2 atomic components. It occurs in the Mott insulating phase where the total flow is arrested. The authors solve here the problem of the dynamic field theoretical description of BCSF. The new model features Borromean hydrodynamics as a low-energy theory representing the symmetry of the U ( 1 ) N factor group. It reveals a counter-flow AC Josephson effect, and generically predicts a first-order phase transition into a BCSF state in dimensions greater than two.

The work highlights moiré engineering as a simple and versatile route to tunable band topology.
